docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A May 26 news article about the death of Robert Payton, a Manhattan lawyer, from a drug overdose after his insurer refused to pay for in-patient drug rehabilitation highlights the decline in coverage for addiction treatment under managed care. This despite estimates showing the economic cost of addiction far exceeds what we invest in treatment.

headline.main: Drug Abuse Is An Insurer's Problem

docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Marc Galanter, president of American Society of Addiction Medicine, on decline in coverage for addiction treatment under managed health care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a year of weak growth, corporate profits rebounded in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. The giant tobacco industry settlement distorted the figures, temporarily fattening the first-quarter number. But the rebound also suggested that the squeeze on profits evident last year may have lifted a bit. The profit report, the first for the January-through-March period, appeared in the Commerce Department's latest estimate of first-quarter economic growth. The gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 4.1 percent, the report said, down somewhat from the 4.5 percent rate reported last month and well below the 6 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter of 1998.

headline.main: Commerce Department Sees Corporate Profit Recovery

docs.abstract: Commerce Department reports Gross Domestic Product grew at annual rate of 4.1 percent in first quarter, down from 4.5 percent in April and well below 6 percent annual rate in fourth qurter of 1998; says GDP grew by 3.9 percent for year ended with first quarter, down from 4.3 percent for year ended with fourth quarter; reports corporate profits rose by 3.9 percent in quarter, to annual rate of $853.5 billion; says 'implicit price deflator' rose 1.4 percent in first quarter; Labor Department says number of Americans filing new claims for state unemployment benefits was 300,000 last week, unchanged from week before; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal officials said today that New York can begin moving more than one million poor people in New York City into managed care health plans as early as July in one of the most ambitious efforts of its kind in the nation, according to state and Federal officials. The state and the city have been seeking approval from Washington for two years to begin the mandatory managed care program in New York City, where most people on Medicaid receive medical coverage under the traditional fee-for-service approach in which medical providers are paid every time a patient is treated.

headline.main: U.S. LETS NEW YORK SHIFT MOST POOR TO MANAGED CARE

docs.abstract: Federal officials say that New York State can begin moving over one million poor people in New York City into managed care health plans as early as July in one of most ambitious efforts of its kind in nation; state and city have been seeking approval for two years to begin mandatory managed care program in city, where most people on Medicaid receive medical coverage under traditional fee-for-service approach; state, under waiver approved by US Health and Human Services Dept, will be allowed to place as many as 1.1 million Medicaid recipients in city into managed care programs during next two years; people with chronic illnesses will be exempt from mandatory program; Giuliani and Pataki administrations praise Federal Government's decision; Government has approved similar waivers from current Medicaid payment system in about dozen other states (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Donald Rose, the head of the Intel Corporation's global drive to prevent Year 2000 computer problems from derailing microchip production, is focused these days on 500 critical suppliers of materials and basic services like power and telephones. About half are ready for the date change, Mr. Rose says. Intel is busy dispatching training, testing and auditing help to the others -- many of them abroad -- in the hope they will catch up. But hope is a high-risk business strategy, so Intel has begun buying backup generators, interviewing alternative suppliers and making other preparations for breakdowns.

headline.main: Worriers, Start Your Engines; Contingency Plans Hit Their Stride for Year 2000

docs.abstract: Article in series, Counting to 2000, focuses on how companies government agencies are for computer problems on Jan 1; says race to repair and test computers that has so far dominated Year 2000 scene is far from over; holds planning to cope with what might go wrong, until recently on 'do later' part of agenda, is now in full swing; says after months of weighing options, businesses and governments are acknowledging that some disruptions are inevitable when computers encounter dates beyond 1999 and that they now face deadlines for investing in contingency plans; says percentage of big companies and government agencies planning to create crisis centers to handle Year 2000 computer problems has more than doubled the last few months; contingency plans at some major companies discussed; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Payton's mother had a premonition that she would never see her son again when she dropped him off at the ferry in Weehawken that muggy day last summer. ''She turned around to wave goodbye to him from the car,'' recalled Mr. Payton's sister, Maureen Hussey, ''and she didn't see him. She told me later that it seemed like an omen to her.'' Mr. Payton was 42, a tall, athletic Manhattan lawyer with dark brown eyes and a fast, bright smile. He had been his family's quick study: magna cum laude from Boston University, a law degree and what looked like a promising legal career ahead. But it never took off, and his family discovered one reason why on a horrible day in January 1998, with a call from a hospital. He had accidentally overdosed on a mix of alcohol, cocaine and other drugs -- his private demons, apparently, for years -- and he lay unconscious for nearly two weeks.

headline.main: Desperate for Treatment, And Battled Every Step; Addicts and Mentally Ill Seen as Vulnerable to H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Robert Payton, Manhattan lawyer, accidentally overdosed on alcohol, cocaine and other drugs in Jan 1998; he fought his HMO, Aetna US Healthcare, to get in-patient drug rehabilitation; it took months of letter-writing and by time Payton was approved, he had died of accidental overdose; medical professionals say Payton's case illustrates growing problem: managed care companies hindering access to mental health and substance abuse services covered in patients' plans; Payton's mother, Dolores, has filed $800 million lawsuit against Aetna; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Yogurt is really sour milk,'' Richard Nicotra said a few days ago. Mr. Nicotra has become the leading private developer of office space on Staten Island in recent years, but as the man who founded the 250-store Everything Yogurt chain 23 years ago, his heart is still very much in the yogurt business. The first store opened in 1976 at 51 Broadway in Manhattan. ''We got the product in liquid form from Colombo Yogurt in Massachusetts and we put it into an ice cream machine to freeze it and whip it,'' Mr. Nicotra said. ''We had vanilla, strawberry and peach. It was a big day when we could manufacture chocolate frozen yogurt.''

headline.main: Going From Yogurt to Developing Office Space on Staten Island

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration intends to require that private health insurance plans for Federal employees provide coverage for severe mental illnesses comparable to that for physical ailments, say Administration officials and Tipper Gore, who is heading a White House conference on mental health next month. Mrs. Gore, the wife of the Vice President, said today that a goal of the White House conference was to eliminate disparities in insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses -- to ''provide parity for all'' while eliminating the stigma of mental illness. A longtime advocate for the rights of the mentally ill, Mrs. Gore disclosed this month that she was treated for clinical depression after her son was injured in an auto accident in 1989.

headline.main: Equal Coverage of Physical and Mental Ills Is White House Goal for Federal Employees

docs.abstract: Tipper Gore says Clinton Administration intends to require that private health insurance plans for Federal employees provide coverage for severe mental illnesses comparable to that for physical ailments; will head White House conference on mental health in June; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to expand one of his most popular programs, President Clinton said today that he would direct the Labor Department to explore ways to allow states to use surplus unemployment insurance funds to subsidize parents who take time off to care for a new child. The President announced the proposed expansion of the Family and Medical Leave law in a commencement address at Grambling State University, a historically black school in north-central Louisiana. Mr. Clinton used the speech to discuss the growing strains faced by working parents and to offer a few nuggets of relief.

headline.main: Clinton Proposes Using Surpluses To Extend Family Leave Benefits

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton says he will direct Labor Department to explore ways to allow states to use surplus unemployment insurance funds to subsidize parents who take time off to care for new child, commencement address at Grambling State University; Clinton also proposes allowing Federal employees to use their accumulted sick leave to care for seriously ill family members; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has never publicly supported a mandate that insurers cover infertility treatments, and his aides say they do not even know his position on the idea. But several Orthodox Jewish leaders in Rockland County say the Governor spoke favorably about it when he met privately with them to seek their backing for the Republican in Tuesday's special election for the State Senate. ''He brought it up and said he would be supportive of it,'' said Rabbi Moshe David Tendler, who heads the Community Synagogue in Monsey, the largest Orthodox congregation in the county. ''It's a real issue in our community, because children are so important. Having 10 children does not raise an eyebrow.''

headline.main: G.O.P. Pulls Out All Stops in a Swing District

docs.abstract: New York Republican leaders are pulling out stops in Rockland and Orange Counties to help Thomas P Morahan win special election for state Senate seat; Rabbi Moshe David Tendler, Orthodox Jewish leader, says Gov George Pataki has promised to support mandate that insurers cover infertility treatments, while Senate leader Joseph Bruno and Morahan himself promise more pork for district; Democrats charge Republicans try to intimidate unions supporting Kenneth Zebrowski; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two brick shelters housing vending machines that dispense soda, juice and other items have sprung up in the middle of Stuyvesant Town in the last two weeks, much to the annoyance of some residents. They say the additions, put up by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the insurer that owns the complex, are unattractive and may pose dangers. ''It looks like a truck stop on I-95,'' said Leigh Anne O'Connor, who has lived in the 8,736-unit development for three and a half years. ''I don't know the wisdom of putting these things up. It's such a wonderful place. Our wonderful little haven.'' The development runs from 14th to 20th Streets and from First Avenue to Avenue C.

headline.main: New Vending Machines Aren't Some Residents' Cup of Tea

docs.abstract: Some residents are opposed to two new brick shelters housing vending machines in middle of Stuyvesant Town apartment complex in NYC; photo (M)
